comment_data.body:
### Skip
    - vim.fs.dir() - mentions both predicate and skip 
    - vim.iter:skip()
    - vim.iter:rskip()
    - search()
    - searchparipos()
    - searchpos()
    - strcharpart()
    - strchars()

### Filter
    - filter()
    - vim.inspect_pos()
    - vim.show_pos()
    - vim.tbl_filter()
    - vim.iter:filter()
    - vim.snippet.active()
    - vim.lsp.buf.code_action() - mentions both filter and predicate
    - vim.lsp.buf.format() - mentions both filter and predicate
    - vim.lsp.buf.rename() - mentions both filter and predicate
    - `filter` is mentions as prefer way to control `enable` functionality in dev-name-common and dev-api-patterns

### Match
    - string:match()
    - string:gmatch()
    - vim.lpeg.Pattern:match()
    - vim.filetype.match()
    - nvim_get_autocmds()
    - vim.regex:match_line()
    - vim.regex:match_str()
    - vim.diagnostic.match()
    - match() and match*() family

### Predicate
    - vim.fs.dir() - mentions both predicate and skip
    - vim.tbl_contains()
    - vim.tbl_filter()
    - vim.iter:all()
    - vim.iter:any()
    - vim.iter:find()
    - vim.iter:rfind()
    - vim.lsp.start() - reuse_client
    - vim.lsp.buf.code_action() - mentions both filter and predicate
    - vim.lsp.buf.format() - mentions both filter and predicate
    - vim.lsp.buf.rename() - mentions both filter and predicate
    - used by TS API

I might had missed some cases but I think this is a general overview of idioms.

it looks like `match` is by far the prefer idiom in the code base since it's used in a lot places to filter/narrow down in various scenarios, although is not so commonly used in as filter mechanism for functions/callbacks, `skip` is actually not that commonly used but is what I picked for `vim.fs.find` since I borrowed the concept from `vim.fs.dir`

the doc for the `names` parameter says:

> If {names} is a function, it is called for each traversed item with args:
> • name: base name of the current item
> • path: full path of the current item The function should return `true` if the given item is considered a match.

```lua
        -- get all files ending with .cpp or .hpp inside lib/
        local cpp_hpp = vim.fs.find(function(name, path)
          return name:match('.*%.[ch]pp$') and path:match('[/\\\\]lib$')
        end, {limit = math.huge, type = 'file'})
```

why can't this be used to skip anything that could conceivably be skipped by the new `skip` parameter in this PR?

@gpanders is `names` intended to provide "skip" functionality or do we need a new `skip` param as in this PR?

> the doc for the `names` parameter says:
> 
> > If {names} is a function, it is called for each traversed item with args:
> > • name: base name of the current item
> > • path: full path of the current item The function should return `true` if the given item is considered a match.

`The function should  return 'true' if the given item is considered a match.` is not suppose to be part of the `path` description, but the vimdoc script did not separate it, also as is now, `names` lazy evaluated the item when a type is provided, in the same example

```lua
-- get all files ending with .cpp or .hpp inside lib/
local cpp_hpp = vim.fs.find(function(name, path)
  return name:match('.*%.[ch]pp$') and path:match('[/\\\\]lib$')
end, {limit = math.huge, type = 'file'})
```
`names` will just evaluate files and wont even see the directories it traverse. it can be changed but in that case the evaluation will be always done for all items all time.

"matching directories" here is referring to `skip` matches, right?

This wording is confusing, because `find()` itself is concerned with matches. Suggestion:

    Stops traversal if it returns false.

P.S. it's confusing that `skip()=false` stops traversal, since I would expected `skip()=true` to perform a "skip"... and this is why I was hesitant about the name "skip". But it's too late now, because `fs.dir` already has `skip`, and we should match it here.

comment_regular_data.body: I think the issue with windows might be cause because VM might not have the permissions create the link in the first place, but at the moment I don't have a windows system to confirm this.

Apparently the problem was indeed permissions related, not on creation but on read, `vim.uv.fs_stat(f)` was getting `EPERM` when the symlink was created without `junction=true` on windows, causing the test to fail.

Please create a separate Pr for the "follow" paramter, so we can unblock it. 

Edit: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31551

want to resolve https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31364#discussion_r1916337288 before merging this.

looks like we are in favor of deprecating `skip` in existing vim.fs functions and renaming it to `filter`.
